Candidatus Vallotiella hemipterorum is a recently discovered and proposed bacterial species that has been found in association with certain hemipteran insects, which include true bugs, cicadas, and aphids. This bacterial species is considered a "Candidatus" designation, meaning it has not yet been formally described and classified according to the standard taxonomic system.

The name "Vallotiella hemipterorum" suggests that this bacterium is related to the Vallotiella genus and is specifically associated with hemipteran insects. Vallotiella is a genus of bacteria within the phylum Bacteroidetes.

Candidatus Vallotiella hemipterorum is believed to be an endosymbiont, meaning it lives within the cells or tissues of its insect host. The exact nature of the relationship between the bacterium and its hemipteran host is not yet fully understood, but it is likely that the bacterium provides some beneficial function to the insect, such as aiding in nutrient acquisition or defense against pathogens.

Further research is needed to fully characterize the morphological, genomic, and functional features of Candidatus Vallotiella hemipterorum, as well as its distribution and prevalence among different hemipteran species. As a newly proposed species, its formal taxonomic classification and the potential implications of its symbiotic relationship with insects are active areas of investigation in the field of microbiology and insect biology.
